title: Electric flux - E is beta r-squared through circle

content.question: A circle of radius <math alttext="0.5 meter" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.5</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math> lies in the <math alttext="x y" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></math> plane with its center at the origin, as shown in the figure. There is an electric field perpendicular to the plane of the figure and with a magnitude given by <math alttext="E of, x and y, equals beta times open parenthesis, x squared plus y squared, close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"><mi>E</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>β</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>, where <math alttext="beta" overflow="scroll"><mi>β</mi></math> is a constant equal to <math alttext="100 newtons per coulomb meters squared" overflow="scroll"><mn>100</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>N/</mtext><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mtext> </mtext><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>. The electric flux through the circle is most nearly

choices.label: <math alttext="10 newton meters squared per coulomb" overflow="scroll"><mn>10</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mtext> </mtext><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>/</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math>
